abstract: Should Bank of America just go ahead and change its name to Bank of the United States of America?
lead_paragraph: Should Bank of America just go ahead and change its name to Bank of the United States of America?

headline.main: Records Say U.S. Pressed BofA to Cut Dividend

abstract: The nation’s 19 biggest banks will start learning Friday how they fared in federal examinations — and which among them will need another bailout.
snippet: The nation’s 19 biggest banks will start learning Friday how they fared in federal examinations — and which among them will need another bailout.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is stressed out about stress tests.

headline.main: Edgy Banks Start to Get Word Today on Stress Tests
headline.print_headline: Edgy Banks Start to Get Word Today On U.S. Tests

abstract: Newly revealed testimony is raising questions about whether federal regulators overstepped their bounds in pressing Bank of America’s acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
snippet: Newly revealed testimony is raising questions about whether federal regulators overstepped their bounds in pressing Bank of America’s acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Newly revealed testimony about federal involvement in the Bank of America acquisition of Merrill Lynch is raising questions about whether bank regulators may have overstepped during a period of extreme stress in the financial system.

abstract: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund said they would increase their lending to poor countries, but they warned that the financial crisis was far from over.
snippet: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund said they would increase their lending to poor countries, but they warned that the financial crisis was far from over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Top officials at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund pledged Thursday to increase their lending to poor countries, warning that the global financial crisis was far from over.

headline.main: Global Finance Officials Promise More Help, but Seek It, Too
headline.print_headline: Global Finance Officials Promise More Help, but Seek It, Too

abstract: Newly revealed testimony about federal involvement in the Bank of America acquisition of Merrill Lynch is raising questions about whether bank regulators may have overstepped during a period of extreme stress in the financial system, The New York Times’s Zachery Kouwe writes.
lead_paragraph: Newly revealed testimony about federal involvement in the Bank of America acquisition of Merrill Lynch is raising questions about whether bank regulators may have overstepped during a period of extreme stress in the financial system, The New York Times’s Zachery Kouwe writes.

headline.main: U.S. Role Questioned in Merrill Deal

abstract: An article in Business Day on Friday about new revelations in testimony by Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman of Bank of America, related to the bank's acquisition of Merrill Lynch misspelled the name of a lawyer who commented on the testimony. He is Randall W. Bodner, not Bonder.
lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Friday about new revelations in testimony by Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman of Bank of America, related to the bank's acquisition of Merrill Lynch misspelled the name of a lawyer who commented on the testimony. He is Randall W. Bodner, not Bonder.

abstract: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School who guest-blogs for the Deal Professor, thinks Bank of America may be able to present a defense of entrapment in lawsuits against it for not disclosing the large losses at Merrill Lynch sooner, since its chief executive says he was pressured by federal regulators not to do so.
snippet: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School who guest-blogs for the Deal Professor, thinks Bank of America may be able to present a defense of entrapment in lawsuits against it for not disclosing the large losses at Merrill Lynch soone...
lead_paragraph: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, occasionally writes as a guest blogger for the Deal Professor. Mr. Henning specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.
